segments.text: Trying a second time to see if the microphone will work, pinning it on my tie, looking out the window in the next room away from the machine, trying to hope that it will work, wondering, wondering if it will this time.
End of test.
We're now on May the 7th, sitting in the front room down on Lee Hollow in Bryan, chatting with Austin Curley, who spells that A-U-S-T-O-N, K-E-R-L-E-Y.
Mr. Curley has been here a long time.
Austin, would you first, for someone who may not know you, who might read this material or listen to the tape,
in the future, would you briefly summarize your experience prior to the time you came back to A&M to join the faculty and staff?
Where did you grow up and when did you get to A&M and so forth?
Well, I think that my mother and father were, they were farmers in Collingwood County.
And things were difficult for them.
I was number four of the four children who survived the time of life.
As a matter of fact, I was a twin, and my twin brother died the first day.
And so it goes.
At the time I was born, our family had left the farm and moved to Bonham, Texas.
I guess in those days that would have been moving to the big city.
We were in Bonham a few years where my father was able to get a job with the Missouri, Kansas, and Texas Railways.
I guess that would be equivalent to today's air or what have you.
Well, we moved from Bonham to Itasca.
He had a better job.
And we lived there for about two years.
And then he moved up the road, so to speak, to Hillsborough.
And there, we were there three or four years.
This painting up here over the clock is the Hillsboro-Cady Railroad Station.
Now, that was where my father worked.
It was a few years later that we're talking about.
There was a platform out at the back where that white horse is.
And so my father bought me a little metal, all metal tricycle and would let me play with it on the platform.
Well, the platform was built to standard height for wagons.
And I was scared to get within 10 feet of the edge, so he had no problems there.
And that was the way he kept me.
And that was so my mother could pick cotton.
And well, we moved to Hillsboro.
And from there, my father, you see the union, you bid on the job.
So he bid on the job at Sherman
And we moved to Sherman in 1921.
It was a fortunate thing for us.
It was a city with excellent schools, three or four colleges, and a very promising community.
We had a library, Carnegie Library.
even at the age of, I was in first grade.
We lived two blocks from the library.
So we made many trips to the library, my sisters and myself and my older brother.
I became an avid reader and I read

They'd have to run me out of the adult section occasionally because they realized I was not ready to read, not so much whether it was, as they say, dirty or not, but it would just be something I wouldn't understand.
So, back to the kids section I would go.
But I became a great supporter of libraries.
I'm that way today.
For several years, I would shelve books at the Bryan Public Library.
Got a big kick out of it, Bill Barzak and I.
Well, I entered the public schools, George Washington Elementary School in Sherman, first grade.
And schooling was relatively easy for me.
I enjoyed it.
I think that as I look back on it, it was fortunate because we had a good quality of teachers.
Teachers were highly regarded, and from good colleges, and the community supported good schools.
Well, I went through elementary, junior high school, as they called it, and then high school.
It was 11 grades then.
And I got off a year early there.
But I graduated with a reasonably good grade.
I worked in the afternoons and on Saturday as a stock boy in the 5 and 10 cent store.
And that was good because I was getting up of an age that I think my parents felt I needed to work.
Work was important.
And I stayed out
of college a year to work and save what I could.
I think that helped me also to kind of get my sights settled better.
So my brother in the meantime had entered Texas A&M in architecture.
But he had a man in Sherman who was backing him, they used to say, to see that he had the money to go.
Well, the sophomore year at A&M for him was a very disastrous thing because in October the bottom fell out of everything.
And about two months later, he came to my brother and told him, he said, I deeply regret this.
But he said, I'm going to be lucky to keep this business.
And all our own family will have to work.
Well, my brother went two years, worked a year, and then two years.
I did the same thing.
I worked.
two years and stayed out and then worked two years.
Now, the library helped me out though because during that year I worked, I figured that if I got a job at Texas A&M, I'd have to have something that would give me an inside approach.
So I decided I would try to work in the library.
So I went down to the librarian at the library and told her what my predicament was.
And she said, yes, she said, I would be willing to work with you.
And if you would, this will take now about three months every night to do what I want you to do.
So we started out.
So I would work all day as a stock boy.
go buy the dairy, which was right behind me.
Now, that is the sale.
And I would buy a quart of milk.
And I would drink a quart of milk, and then I would head out for the library.
Well, in about three months, why, she finally said, I think you're ready to work in the library.
And they carried me through all the departments.
So I wrote Dr. Mayo, Thomas F. Mayo, a great man, in my opinion.
And I told him, I've done all this work.
I sent my only copy that I had of anything in writing because there was no way in those days to make a copy.
I don't know what ever happened to it, but they did write back and say I could expect to be used in the library.
So I started next to him in the fall of 34, and I majored in economics.
To tell you the truth, I didn't want else to major.
In 1934, liberal arts students had a little, quite a bit of hazing.
What do you think you're going to do with that when you get through?
Well, it was all right.
It was in good spirits, and you learned by listening.
There are ways of coming back with that, but you have to listen to people that know what to say.
Well, I...
I did well in my grades, but I learned a lot the hard way.
In the first semester that I was in school, I had better than a B. I thought, you know, I'm going to get all this.
I can't.
So I was eligible, so I took 21 hours.
The second semester, well, I was working 20 hours.
Well, I thought I was going to die, but I was too stubborn to back out.
So I made the semester all right, but I learned a lesson.
I learned a lesson to be able to.
I never will forget, I walked into that college.
It was in psychology.
And I was the only freshman in the class.
And that, in 1934, a freshman in a class of juniors and seniors was not particularly welcomed.
And there was a senior in the class, though.
And he said, fisherman, what are you doing taking that course?
And I told him.
He said, well, what do you think?
I said, I think I made a mistake.
He said, well, come around, I'll help you.
So I learned one of many, many lessons.
Well, the life in the Corps was very variable to me because I had a life that was expectancy was clear and concise.
and you had confidence that it would happen, and you could depend on it.
My roommate was a Mexican-American boy from San Antonio, Rudolfo San Miguel.
Now, how did you two get linked up as roommates?
Do you know?
I don't know, but I have a hunch.
The company commander

Mr. Allen had been a freshman under my brother see I didn't have any better sense but go get in the same company my brother had been in I didn't have much sense on some of those things well Mr. Allen Mr. Allen put us together and I I loved that man like a brother
How were Hispanics treated in the student body then?
They were treated cordially.
Now, when it came to social events, neither one particularly wanted to do what the other wanted to do.
But in the company itself, well, now,
Rudolfo had a brother, Arturo San Miguel, who was a sophomore.
He started here early.
These two men both were distinguished students every semester they went.
Arturo was a mechanical engineering graduate, and Rudolfo was an architect.
I was very fortunate.
These two young men were true gentlemen.
Courteous, funny, fun-loving, but respected your privacy.
Yes, they were great.
During the years, I visited his family in San Antonio.
He came up to Sherman and visited my family.
And we...
we, we had great regard for each other.
I, later, there, there, we, the junior year, we had, we had another Mexican-American, that, two of them and myself.
He had, he had been a
worker in the dining hall, and then there were barracks back of Sebesta where single men could live, and he lived in there.
Well, he would, he fought his way through, he finally graduated.
Well, the, now, Rudolfo had a five-year program
So the year I stayed out, evened us up, and it was a good arrangement.
Well, I got my degree, and I had worked in the summers for the AAA, the Cotton Program.
And I was offered a job, two or three jobs, in Dallas.
But I didn't want to go to Dallas.
Well, I think I simply had not found what I really wanted to do.
And maybe that was the excuse.
But I worked for the AAA from June until about April.
was offered a job with the Farm Credit Administration out of Dallas as a field supervisor on emergency crop lawns, drought and things like that.
Well, it was a good job, and in the meantime, Melba and I were married in the fall of 39.
And she had been an art major at Texas State College for Women.
TSCW then.
Yeah, it was, well, her first year was CIA.
CIA.
Well, we were detailed to, or sent to Crockett,
And I had five counties.
Crawford was the most eastern point, and Hearn was the other end of it.
And this was a very pleasant two years before World War II broke out.
World War II broke out, and I was sent my greetings, of course, pretty quick.
and I was on the cadre of the 90th Infantry Division and I enjoyed my duty as a platoon leader.
I stayed with that cadre through the battalion maneuvers and then I was ordered
that what's called the detached officer list, I think, where you are pulled out and I was assigned ROTCU and sent to New Mexico A&M at Las Cruces.
Well I had a very, we moved out there, had a very interesting time and I
found a great deal of interest and satisfaction in working with these young men and it was just kind of like finding a home.
Well, I stayed there a year and we also were operating the Army Specialized Training Program.
This

wrote a book about it someone did scholars and foxholes well those young scholars in the february of 44 found themselves down for dealing with truth and i i i really feel that was a bad faith on the part of federal government because i had men in my company that had were tech sergeants
And they lost it all.
Instead of getting their rank back, they were sent and replaced.
Well, I was sent from Las Cruces to Arlington, and I stayed there a year.

uh while i was at arlington i was detailed to the command general staff college as a student with the zone of interior course and rated a superior i i like the military but i like teaching better i could have it both
Well, I think that that was a significant point in my life, that I almost had my future structured as I went through this.
Well, when the war was over, and I was sent back to making cattle feed loans, I knew I had to get back.
So we came back to Sherman.
And we made it through a difficult three or four months.
And then I was offered a position with the Sherman Public Schools to organize the first distributive education program in the school.
And that fitted my structure because these young people
were in school, and then would work in the afternoon training stations.
And I deeply enjoyed this.
I did this two years, and then I realized I should be getting on with graduate school.
So we talked about it.
In the meantime, at that point, we had four children.
And Melvin said, well, if we're going to have this family and we've got them, we're not going to make it on just you teaching.
So she said, we'll go over to Denton and you do your graduate work, and I'll see what I can do about completing my undergraduate.
So we did this.
And we were there in Denton for two years.
And I finished a master's and got accepted in their doctoral program, the first one.
I was in the first one.
And you see, I could leave my work at Foreign Astronomy, for example, and take a course.
And it was very meaningful.
about that time the public schools in Sherman asked me to please come back and they wanted me to be vice principal of the hospital and director of guidance.
I had a principal who was very progressive and
and I was ready.
I had gotten proper training.
I started my degree in business administration, but I changed over to guidance.
Well, I went over to Sherman, Melba State at Denton with the children, and my wife's brother
came over from Sherman to enter graduate school.
He was a naval veteran.
So he would stay at our house.
And then on Friday he would come home and I would come home.
Well, we worked this out.
And then in March of that year,
I had a telephone call from Dr. Bertram at the basic division down here.
And he said, I want to talk to you about coming to Texas A&M.
And so Alvin and I went down on Friday, and we were still having classes on Saturdays.
Dean Bertrand told me about the Basic Division.
And really, Haskell's Basic Division was nothing in the world but a strong guidance-centered structure, but with academic emphasis.
And that fitted my background very well.
And I felt very comfortable about being able to handle relationships with the Corps.
Now, this was what year?
March of 52.
All right.
And then when does he offer you?
He offered me a job about the next week.
What was the beginning pay?
$4,000, I believe.
For 12 months.
Well, he said, we will try for 12 months.
See, we also, that, you know, I came down here with great enthusiasm and support of this program.
Because, and the remarkable thing was that the major person in it was an engineer, Mr. Gilchrist.
And he foresaw
the difficulty that the freshman students were having in the freshman year.
So he put the first year students all out at the air base.
Now was that still, when you came that fall of 52, were they freshmen still out?
No, because in 51,
You see, the war broke out with Korea.
Oh, and that took place.
And so they said we got to have this facility back.
So you began September?
No, I began July the 1st, 1952.
At that point, describe the campus physically.
What buildings, what were the primary buildings where?
Oh, there's little or no difference except the Memorial Student Center.
No difference from?
Okay, but make believe that I had never seen the campus.
Well, now the YMCA was still...
a very important cog in the life, off-campus life.
It was still functioning.
But the Memorial Student Center was sort of the exciting point on the campus, because here was a place that parents could come and find restrooms.
Now, I presume that for you people of your experience, the MSC was almost luxurious.
Oh, yes.
Yes, I was sort of awed, actually.
It was so far beyond.
Now, I don't mean to be critical here because when I was a student, like all the other fellows will tell you,
If we had a dance on a weekend in the spring, one of the poor dorms, and of course they were all poor except the international, they'd choose one, Hart Hall.
I was in Hart Hall two years, and we always got caught.
But we would take out.
We would get our gear together and leave the dormitory and
And don't think it wasn't clean when we left.
And the young ladies would use that?
Yes.
This MSC, you and I both knew Wayne Stark well.
Describe young Wayne Stark when you first came back.
Well, Wayne was an excellent...
